stem: A client is found somnolent with a respiratory rate of 6. Based on the documentation in the PCA Pump Log & Clinical History, which finding represents the MOST LIKELY root cause of the client's condition?

options.text: A technical pump malfunction leading to continuous delivery
The client's age (82) causing increased sensitivity to opioids
A miscalculation of the demand dose by the physician

rationale.correct: The MOST LIKELY and dangerous root cause here is **PCA-by-proxy (a1)**. The family member admitted to pushing the demand button while the client was asleep. This is a critical safety violation; the principle of PCA is that the *patient* only receives a dose when *alert* enough to trigger it. If someone else pushes it while the patient is asleep, the natural 'safety stop' (sedation) is bypassed, leading to respiratory depression. While the pump log also shows a 'technical error' (a2), the clinical history of unauthorized button-pushing is the primary human-factor failure and the MOST LIKELY cause given the information provided.
clinicalPearls: Only the PATIENT may push the PCA button. No family, No nurses.
PCA-by-proxy is a leading cause of fatal opioid overdoses in the hospital setting.
The 'Safety' of PCA is based on the feedback loop: If the patient is too sleepy to push the button, they don't get more drugs.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing the technical pump error (a2) because it's listed in the log.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: NCLEX often pits human error against technical error. In the context of PCA, the unauthorized user (proxy) is the 'classic' NCLEX safety hazard you must identify. While the pump malfunctioned, the family member's actions are the more direct and likely cause of the respiratory depression.

mnemonic.title: Self-Service Only
mnemonic.expansion: Patient pushes, patient stays. Family pushes, patient pays (overdose).

exhibits.title: Post-Incident Assessment
exhibits.content: Examination: The secondary infusion line (PCA) shows that the security lock is 'Engaged but Faulty.' The pump display screen is flickering. Multiple demand doses were registered even though the client was asleep.

exhibits.title: Patient History
exhibits.content: Age: 82. Condition: Osteoarthritis. No prior opioid use. Client's family member states: 'I've been pushing the button whenever he looked like he was in pain while sleeping.'
